w.t: time woman spends in house between birth of child and time she goes out
corner of field belonging to each child
to put on new bark, new growth
to cause to put on new growth
to come up out of water
to be caused to sit, stay
to punish by death on the spot
to pay to make up for wrong doing
to sneak out of an argument or obligation
to slip out little by little (of nail, etc.)
to wash oneself in lots of water
to tell to others what you've heard
to return of one's own will
to leave off speaking evil and speak kindly
to go to a man's house to entice him
to go to a meal uninvited
to do something of oneself without authority
to boast of what one will do
arrive at (e.g. har'aho wigeze kumubona? - have you ever seen him?)
to make oneself equal to another
to help oneself (even if you don't know how to do tbe thing)
to rejoice in coming of another
to rejoice together, in each other
to make it hard for oneself
to tie or attach oneself to
to take out sliver for oneself
to sacrifice oneself to or for
to give of one's own accord
to pay bribe to win one's case
to rub sleepers from one's eyes
to die (used of a person scorned by others
to not know what to do
to go walking (esp. at night) (of king)
ndakwikebanuye - goodbye (used when addressing a superior
to go aside with someone to talk privately
to be in one's own light
to cleanse house ceremoniously after a death
to do the same exercise repeatedly
--hasi or, imbere - to fall down before
to refuse to give to another
to plan secretly to do something
(1st cl.) brother of his, her, their mother
(1st cl.) sister of his, her, their father
to take grain out of water
to fail to keep a vow
to do that which you declared you wouldn't
to devote oneself to task in order to finish it
to tell how one's affairs are going
to stop of one's own accord
to put off doing what one should
to not give answer when asked
to acknowledge to oneself one's guilt
to spend the whole day at a certain task
to go into danger without regard to oneself
gift to make up for offending someone
to assist one in trouble or grief
to make a sick person lean on one
to lean on (esp. in getting up)
to make fun of (esp. of someone in trouble)
to pay debts to each other
to be pressed to pay a debt
(1st cl.) child of one's sister (if one is a boy) (often used in oaths)
wreath (such as put around basket with gift)
to dress a wound for oneself
(euphemistically used for to commit adultery - in speaking of a married man)
to devote oneself to a task
to warm oneself by the fire (lit. ,roast oneself)
to be determined to get what you want
to put yourself above where you belong
to warm oneself by the fire
to name because of, in memory of
to not be in a hurry
to be always looking for a quarrel
to take something out of one ts own eye
to reinforce the words of another
to take load off one's own head

ndakwitwayeko - I've come to you for something (respectful way to begin one's request)
to be eager, earnest, zealous, persistent
to admit one's wrong to avoid being caught
to tell what one has done
to try to find food for unexpected guests
to say mean things in trying to provoke another
